questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

choices.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement
To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

 

Incorrect. While a frozen section can provide rapid results, it does not replace the need for a formal and thorough pathological examination of paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The frozen section technique can sometimes result in artifacts that make interpretation challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine sentinel lymph node involvement: Correct. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed during breast cancer surgery, and a frozen section of the node can be examined to determine if there's cancerous involvement. If positive, complete axillary lymph node clearance can be done.

 

Option B. To assess margin positivity: Correct. During breast-conserving surgeries, the surgeon aims to remove the tumor along with a rim of normal tissue. A frozen section can be used to immediately check if the margins (edges) of the removed tissue are free of cancer cells. If cancer cells are found at the margin, additional tissue can be removed during the same procedure.

 

Option C. To evaluate metastasis: Correct. The frozen section can be used to evaluate if there's metastasis to the lymph nodes or other tissues sampled during the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

 

Telmisartan is the appropriate choice for a hypertensive patient with an elevated HbA1c level (8.1%), indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Telmisartan, an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), has unique properties among ARBs due to its partial agonistic activity on peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma). PPAR-gamma agonists can improve insulin sensitivity and have beneficial effects on glycemic control. This makes Telmisartan particularly useful for patients managing both hypertension and diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not have the beneficial effects on glycemic control seen with Telmisartan and would not be the preferred choice in a patient with elevated HbA1c.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. While effective for hypertension, beta-blockers can potentially worsen glycemic control and are not ideal for patients with diabetes.

 

Option D. Olmesartan: Olmesartan is another ARB, but unlike Telmisartan, it lacks PPAR-gamma agonistic activity. Thus, it does not offer the additional benefit of improving insulin sensitivity and glycemic control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.

 

Option C. Syphilis: A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 926

choices.text: It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph
It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given
It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug
It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

questions.text: A new drug is tested in clinical trials and was found to have a therapeutic index of 20. Which of the following statements best describes the therapeutic index of the drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

 

The therapeutic index (TI) refers to LD50/ED50.

 

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50

 

Where,

 

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the lethal dose at which 50% of the subjects died.

  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the dose at which 50% of the subjects get the desired response.

 

The therapeutic index is therefore the margin of safety for a drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph: This statement describes bioavailability, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option B. It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given: This statement describes the volume of distribution (Vd), not the therapeutic index.

 

Option C. It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug: This statement describes the drug's half-life, not the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index (TI) is a crucial parameter that represents the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as the ratio of LD50 to ED50, indicating the range between an effective dose and a potentially lethal dose. A higher TI indicates a safer drug with a wider margin of safety.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Hall-Wellner Band

 

  • The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a graphical representation commonly used in survival analysis to display the probability of an event, typically survival, over time.
  • It is particularly useful when studying the time to a specific event, such as death or disease progression.
  • The Kaplan-Meier curve often incorporates bands around the survival estimate, which represent the confidence interval.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, Gill bands, and Nair's Equal Precision confidence bands are used for this purpose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unequal precision band: Not a standard term used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option B. Hirshberg band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option C. Holmes band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command - 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

 

Ivermectin has been extensively studied during the COVID-19 pandemic but has not demonstrated any proven efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infection. Despite creating headlines during the pandemic period, clinical studies have not provided strong evidence that ivermectin reduces the risk of transmission or acquisition of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask: Wearing masks has been proven to be an effective preventive measure in reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by providing a physical barrier against respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vaccine: Vaccines serve as pre-exposure prophylaxis and have been demonstrated to be effective in preventing severe COVID-19 infection and reducing transmission.

 

Option D. Cough etiquette: Proper cough etiquette is an important preventive measure that helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text:
What is the sequence of performing a Thomas test?(INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Passive flexion of affected hip
  2. Overcorrection on the normal side
  3. Measure the flexion angle
  4. Checking for lumbar lordosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV, II, I, III

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:

 

Checking for lumbar lordosis

                        ↓

Overcorrection on the normal side

                        ↓

Passive flexion of affected hip

                        ↓

Measure the flexion angle

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome which is associated with severe pain; hence the most likely diagnosis here would be herpes zoster or shingles.
  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This is a viral infection of the skin that causes small, pearly, or flesh-coloured bumps. The lesions are typically umbilicated, meaning they have a small indentation or dimple at the centre as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Option D. Lymphangioma circumscriptum: This condition presents as vesicles filled with lymphatic fluid as shown in the image below. It typically does not have the painful, dermatomal distribution seen in herpes zoster.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

choices.text: Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity
PD1/ PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

 

CTLA4 is a negative regulator of T-cell responses. recognition of tumor cells may lead to engagement of the T-cell inhibitory receptor, CTLA4, or activation of regulatory T cells that suppress immune responses. Antibodies that block the interaction of CTLA-4 with its ligands B7. 1 and B7. 2 can enhance immune responses, including anti-tumor immunity.

 

Ipilimumab, a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal Anti CTLA-4 antibody, has shown a significant improvement in survival of advanced-stage melanoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity: This statement is incorrect because mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53) lead to the loss of cell cycle control and contribute to tumorigenesis, not decreased antigen toxicity.

 

Option C. PD1/PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression: The PD-1/PD-L1 pathway is another immune checkpoint that, when activated, suppresses the immune response. In cancer, tumors often upregulate PD-L1 to evade immune destruction, so this pathway is involved in immune evasion, not suppression of tumors.

 

Option D. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 is a co-stimulatory molecule that, when bound to B7 on APCs, promotes T-cell activation rather than tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-CTLA-4 antibodies like Ipilimumab are a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers, enhancing the anti-tumor immune response by blocking inhibitory signals to T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 574

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: What is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileocecal junction

 

The ileocecal junction is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis. This area, which includes the terminal ileum and the beginning of the large intestine (cecum), is particularly susceptible to infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The lymphoid tissue in this region provides a favorable environment for the bacteria to proliferate.

 

Abdominal tuberculosis can present in two primary forms: hypertrophic and ulcerative. The hypertrophic form involves thickening of the intestinal wall, while the ulcerative form leads to the formation of ulcers. Clinically, differentiating abdominal tuberculosis from Crohn's disease can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms and similar radiologic findings. In some cases, empirical anti-tubercular therapy (ATP) may be initiated, with subsequent monitoring for clinical improvement to help distinguish between the two conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectum: The rectum is not a common site for abdominal tuberculosis. Tuberculosis primarily affects the ileocecal region and less frequently involves other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Colon: While tuberculosis can affect the colon, it is not the most common site. The ileocecal junction is more frequently involved in abdominal tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Small intestine: Although the small intestine can be affected, the terminal ileum specifically, which is part of the ileocecal junction, is the most common site for tuberculosis within the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site of abdominal tuberculosis is the ileocecal junction, particularly near the terminal ileum. This region's lymphoid tissue creates a favorable environment for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to proliferate.

questions.text:
Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body?(INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Eye

2. Testes

3. Kidney

4. Gut

5. Lungs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,2,3,4,5 are correct

 

The countercurrent mechanism is present in various parts of the body where the inflow and outflow run parallel and in opposite directions, facilitating efficient exchange processes:

 

  1. Eye: The theory of counter-current mechanisms predicts that there is diffusion of oxygen from retinal arterioles into adjacent retinal venules. A possible counter-current exchange was investigated by measuring hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SatO2) in first-order retinal arterioles and venules at different distances from the optic disc.
  2. Testes: The temperature is regulated to be low for spermatogenesis by heat exchange between spermatic arteries and veins in a countercurrent manner.
  3. Kidney: The urine is concentrated using countercurrent exchangers, particularly in the loop of Henle and the vasa recta.
  4. Gut: Certain parts of the gut use countercurrent mechanisms to optimize nutrient absorption.
  5. Lungs: Countercurrent mechanisms in the lungs help in efficient gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The countercurrent mechanism is a biological system found in various organs such as the eye, testes, kidney, gut, and lungs, allowing for efficient exchange and regulation processes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.
  3. They are of 7 types.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Sirtuins are a family of proteins that have been widely studied for their role in regulating various cellular processes, including aging, metabolism, and stress responses. Here's a detailed breakdown of each statement:

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1, have been shown to enhance insulin sensitivity and promote glucose metabolism, which is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity: Sirtuins are known to regulate gene expression in ways that promote longevity. They are involved in the deacetylation of proteins that contribute to cell survival, repair, and metabolism, which are associated with extended lifespan in various organisms.
  3. They are of 7 types: There are seven known sirtuins in humans, designated SIRT1 through SIRT7, each with specific functions in different cellular compartments.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases: Sirtuins function as NAD+-dependent deacetylases, a class of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histone and non-histone proteins, influencing gene expression and protein activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.

questions.text: All of the following artery demonstrates Windkessel effect except: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial artery

 

Radial artery can show Windkessel effect, but among the given options, it is the most peripheral artery. As we move from center to periphery the elasticity property in the artery decreases, hence least Windkessel effect is seen in the radial artery hence it is the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal artery: The renal artery demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its proximity to the aorta and its elastic properties.

 

Option C. Aorta: The aorta is a primary example of a vessel demonstrating the Windkessel effect.

 

Option D. Carotid artery:  The carotid artery also demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its elastic properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINDKESSEL VESSELS

 

Large elastic arteries contain Elastin protein → elastic recoil

 

Ex: - Aorta & large arteries (e.g. Pulmonary Artery, Carotid, Renal artery)

 

  • During systole → Ventricle → eject blood → aorta gets stretched
  • During Diastole → Aortic recoil → DBP
  • At old age → Aortic stenosis → elasticity → hardening of aorta → SBP →DBP→PP

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

choices.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.

 

Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.

 

Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rdedition Pg207

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypomenorrhea

 

  • Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur because of
    • Trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion.
    • Genital tuberculosis
  • C/F: Following a D & C, they present with
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • The diagnosis is made by
    • HSG: Moth eaten appearance/ intra cavitary filling defects
    • Hysteroscopy: Intra uterine adhesions are seen

 

 

  • Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis f/b insertion of an IUCD for 3 months and giving estrogen to build the endometrium

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligomenorrhea: This refers to infrequent menstruation, which is not the primary symptom of Asherman syndrome. Although it can occur, hypomenorrhea is more characteristic of the condition.

 

Option C. Dysmenorrhea: This means painful menstruation, which is not typically associated with Asherman syndrome.

 

Option D. Menorrhagia: This refers to heavy menstrual bleeding. Asherman syndrome usually leads to hypomenorrhea rather than menorrhagia due to the reduced endometrial surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with hypomenorrhea due to intrauterine adhesions following endometrial trauma.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the site X shown in the figure? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrochlorothiazide

 

The site X in the given image represent distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is a thiazide diuretic that acts by blocking the Na-Cl symporter in the DCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle (marked B) and inhibits the Na-K-2Cl symporter.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Is an Aldosterone receptor blocker acting on the collecting ducts (marked Y).

 

Option D. Acetazolamide. Is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubules (marked A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and promoting diuresis. This makes it effective for treating conditions such as hypertension and edema. Other diuretics like furosemide, spironolactone, and acetazolamide act on different parts of the nephron and have distinct mechanisms of action.

questions.text: Match the following teratogenic drugs with their teratogenic effects: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correctly matched pairs of teratogenic drugs and their effects is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

 

  1. Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders and prophylaxis of mania. It is c/I in pregnancy as it leads to Ebstein’s anomaly in the fetus, which is characterised by arterialization of the right ventricle and a box shaped heart.
  2. Warfarin leads to defect in the growth of the cartilage (chondrodysplasia punctata) characterized by depressed nasal bridge, stippled epiphyses etc. Warfarin embryopathy is maximally seen when it is used between 6-9 weeks.
  3. Thalidomide causes proximal limb defect or Phocomelia. Thalidomide acts via inhibiting angio-genesis, inhibiting cereblon and suppressing immune responses.
  4. Chloramphenicol inhibits peptidyl transferase. It causes Bone Marrow suppression and leads to grey baby syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The teratogenic effects of certain drugs is crucial for managing medication use during pregnancy. Lithium can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, Warfarin is associated with saddle nose and growth retardation, Thalidomide causes limb malformations, and Chloramphenicol can lead to Grey Baby Syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, and a peripheral smear showing the presence of smudge cells suggest a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+, CD20+, CD 23+, CD5+ and surface immunoglobulins of various classes, monoclonal light chains (λ or κ type).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): While PCR can be useful in certain hematologic malignancies for detecting specific genetic mutations, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH can be used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can provide additional prognostic information by identifying chromosomal abnormalities but is typically done after confirming the diagnosis with flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient suspected of having Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), Flow cytometry is the key diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

 

Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1114

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

 

Blackening around the entry wound is primarily due to the deposition of smoke and soot produced from the burning propellant (gunpowder). This is most notable at close range and creates a dark mark surrounding the entry site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat Fire Effect : This involves the heat generated by the discharge of a firearm. It can cause singeing of the hair and possibly burning of the skin around the wound, but it does not usually cause blackening.

 

Option B. Muzzle of Firearm Weapon : This refers to the end of the gun barrel. While the muzzle is close to the skin, it may deposit soot and cause burns, but it is not itself a cause of blackening. It's more about proximity effects.

 

Option C. Unburnt Gunpowder Particles : When a gun is fired, unburnt particles of gunpowder can exit the muzzle along with the bullet. These particles can cause stippling or tattooing around the wound, which is not the same as blackening but related to small abrasions on the skin.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

 

Explanation:

 

The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.

 

  • Complications of central vein catheterization are - 
    • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
    • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
    • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
    • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
    • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
    • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
    • Infections

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombophlebitis: Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

 

Option C. Empyema: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

 

Option D. Chylothorax: Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with intussusception and is taken up for surgery. The surgeon found multiple polyps and sent the resected section for histopathology. The image is given below. What is the type of lesion? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

The image and clinical scenario point towards a hamartomatous polyp, particularly because of the patient's young age and the finding of multiple polyps. Hamartomatous polyps are generally solitary lesions but can be multiple in certain syndromes, such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and juvenile polyposis syndrome, which are more common in children and adolescents.

 

Hamartomatous polyps are benign, disorganized growths of tissue that are normally found in the location where they arise. In the context of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, these polyps are associated with an increased risk of intussusception due to their size and location in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type of adenoma has both tubular and villous features and is typically found in older adults, with a higher risk of malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Villous Adenoma: These are the most dangerous types of adenomas due to their higher potential for malignancy, but they are usually seen in older patients and have a distinctive villous histological appearance.
